Identify Reference Fortnight in PNADC Data

Source: R/identify-reference-fortnight.R
identify_reference_fortnight.Rd

PNADC is a quarterly survey where each interview occurs during a specific fortnight within the quarter. This function identifies which fortnight (1-6 per quarter, 1-24 per year) that observation belongs to, enabling bi-weekly time series analysis.

The algorithm uses:

  • IBGE's reference week timing rules (first Saturday with sufficient days in month)

  • Respondent birthdates to constrain possible interview dates

  • UPA-panel level aggregation (everyone in same sampling unit interviewed together)

  • Dynamic exception detection (identifies quarters needing relaxed rules)

Usage

identify_reference_fortnight(data, verbose = TRUE, .pb = NULL, .pb_offset = 0L)

Arguments

data

A data.frame or data.table with PNADC microdata. Required columns:

  • Ano: Survey year

  • Trimestre: Quarter (1-4)

  • UPA: Primary Sampling Unit

  • V1008: Household sequence within UPA

  • V1014: Panel identifier

  • V2008: Birth day (1-31)

  • V20081: Birth month (1-12)

  • V20082: Birth year

  • V2009: Age

verbose

Logical. If TRUE (default), display progress information.

.pb

Optional progress bar object.

.pb_offset

Integer. Offset for progress bar updates.

Value

A data.table with the original key columns plus:

  • ref_fortnight: Reference fortnight as Date (1st or 16th of month)

  • ref_fortnight_in_quarter: Position in quarter (1-6) or NA

  • ref_fortnight_yyyyff: Integer YYYYFF format (1-24 per year)

Details

Determines which fortnight (quinzena - 15-day period) within each quarter corresponds to each survey observation based on IBGE's interview timing rules.

Fortnight Definition

Each year has 24 fortnights (2 per month):

  • Fortnight 01: Jan 1-15

  • Fortnight 02: Jan 16-31

  • Fortnight 03: Feb 1-15

  • Fortnight 04: Feb 16-28/29

  • ... and so on through fortnight 24 (Dec 16-31)

Each quarter has 6 fortnights (e.g., Q1 = fortnights 01-06).

Expected Determination Rate

Fortnight determination rate is typically low (~2-5%) because:

  • Unlike months, fortnights cannot aggregate across quarters

  • Birthday constraints typically narrow the date range by only a few weeks

  • A 15-day fortnight window is difficult to pinpoint without cross-quarter data

The algorithm determines fortnight when the interview date range falls entirely within a single 15-day period.

Note: The month algorithm achieves ~97% determination by aggregating at UPA-V1014 level across ALL quarters (leveraging the panel design where the same units are interviewed in consistent relative positions). Fortnights and weeks cannot use this cross-quarter aggregation because their positions are not consistent across panel visits.

See also

pnadc_identify_periods for the main function that builds a complete crosswalk including months, fortnights, and weeks. identify_reference_month for month-only identification. identify_reference_week for week-only identification.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Identify reference fortnights
result <- identify_reference_fortnight(pnadc_data)

# Check determination rate by quarter
result[, .(
  total = .N,
  determined = sum(!is.na(ref_fortnight_in_quarter)),
  rate = mean(!is.na(ref_fortnight_in_quarter))
), by = .(Ano, Trimestre)]

# Note: Fortnight determination rate is typically low (~2-5%)
# because fortnights cannot aggregate across quarters like months can.
} # }
